title: Eddie Murphy announced as Wall Street Journal 2019 Entertainment Innovator
text:
He's flying high on some of the best reviews of his career for his hit Netflix film Dolemite Is My Name.

Now Eddie Murphy has been named the Wall Street Journal's 2019 Entertainment Innovator.

The paper's wide-ranging interview with the 58–year–old actor and comedian comes ahead of his return to hosting Saturday Night Live 35 years after he was a regular castmember.

He's back! Eddie Murphy, 58, was named the Wall Street Journal's 2019 Entertainment Innovator and featured in a lengthy interview with the paper published Monday

Eddie's interview comes amid a career renaissance for the iconic funnyman.

He's set to star in a sequel to his comedy classic Coming To America, as well as a reboot of his hit Beverly Hills Cop.

He'll also be making a long-awaited return to stand-up comedy after forsaking the medium for poorly reviewed and under-performing films.

But when asked about his stand-up return, Eddie made it sound as if he's only making a temporary return.

'I always wanted to do stand-up one more time. So I want to get that done,' he said.

More to come: Eddie's return comes amid a well-reviewed performance in Dolemite Is My Name, plans to host SNL again in December, and his long-awaited return to stand-up comedy

Fortuitous: His new high-profile projects were just the luck of timing. These things were in development, Dolemite, Coming 2 America and Beverly Hills Cop,' he explained

As for his recent spate of popular and much-anticipated movies, a lot of it was just the luck of timing.

'With movies, it was like, I don’t want the last movie I do to be Mr. Church. These things were in development, Dolemite, Coming 2 America and Beverly Hills Cop,' he explained.

'I’ve been, you know, trying to get them done for 15 years. Dolemite came together and it’s like, "oh, wow, this is perfect."'

That perfect feeling doesn't necessarily mean there'll be many more movies following on their heels.

'Once I get back onstage, I kind of feel like that’s what I was born to do more than anything,' he said. 'When I get back on the stage, I can’t imagine wanting to do movies again.'

Back at it: Eddie's new Dolemite Is My Name has been called a return to form by critics and is a return to the smart yet raunchy films that he made his name with

No more films? 'Once I get back onstage, I kind of feel like that’s what I was born to do more than anything,' he said. 'When I get back on the stage, I can’t imagine wanting to do movies again'

Too much work: The Trading Places star claimed that the long hours and hard work of making movies made him hesitant to keep going

Murphy's less-positive view of filmmaking stemmed from the rigorous requirements and time-consuming nature of the art form.

'What I like to do more than anything is just be home with my family, chilling. It’s really easy to feel like you’re working when you make a movie,' he said. 'You’ve got to get up at five, six in the morning. I started making movies when I was 20 years old, when I made 48 Hrs.. That’s f***ing 38 years.

'You’ve been on a movie set, you see how this s*** is. It’s not a fun process. Once I get back onstage again, I want to do whatever, be funny — I can do that whenever I want to,' he added.

Eddie's newest film, Dolemite Is My Name, stars the comedian as Rudy Ray Moore, the cult comedian who starred in a series of blaxploitation films based on a tough-talking, braggadocious character Dolemite.

'When I see Rudy Ray Moore, it’s how audacious he was. How edgy. That’s what stuck out most,' he explained.

Not scared: Eddie wasn't fazed when asked about 'woke' challenges to stand-up. 'It was always like that... People would talk s***, get bent out of shape. I had to apologize for stuff. And that was, you know, 30 years ago. Now everybody gets treated the same way'

The Mark Twain Prize winner also delved into the changing nature of stand-up comedy and addressed the so-called 'woke people versus stand-up' dynamic.

'It was always like that... People would talk s***, get bent out of shape. I had to apologize for stuff. And that was, you know, 30 years ago,' he said.

'Now everybody gets treated the same way. But it’s not like I’m looking at it like, “Oh, now I don’t know if I can do stand-up because it’s changed.” It’s like, it changed for everyone else. That’s the way it always was for me.

'The difference is now I’m sitting and seeing how s*** is. So when I put my stuff together, I ain’t stepping on nobody’s toes, giving nobody reasons to picket me and all that s***,' he added.

Weary but confident: 'I’m curious to see what happens when I put it all together and get onstage. I hope to live up to everybody’s expectations. Whatever it is, it’s going to be me'

After claiming that he wants to take his new stand-up material to the biggest venues and across the globe, the Trading Places star concluded by addressing the sky-high expectations for his new jokes.

'Everybody’s got this expectation. I don’t even know what’s going to come out. I know I’m still the same dude. I’m still the same person. I’m older, and I’ve changed the way people change when you get older,' he said.

'But whatever mechanism made me funny, how I come up with jokes — I’ll be at the house and funny s*** still comes out of my mouth.

'I’m curious to see what happens when I put it all together and get onstage. I hope to live up to everybody’s expectations. Whatever it is, it’s going to be me.'

Eddie will host NBC's Saturday Night Live on December 21.
description: Eddie Murphy was named the Wall Street Journal's Entertainment Innovator for 2019. The actor and comedian talked about his long-awaited return to stand-up and his current career revival.
